summary.title: Web Application Login Threat Model For Splace Market Place
summary.description:
This is a web application login system that allows users to authenticate using a username and password. 
The application connects to a backend database to verify credentials and establishes a user session upon successful login. 
The system runs on a public web server and stores user credentials in the database.

diagrams.title: Login Flow Diagram

threats.title: User Identity Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker may attempt to impersonate a legitimate user by stealing or forging credentials.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strong password policies.

Use MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication).

Lock accounts after multiple failed login attempts.

Implement secure session management.

threats.title: Lack of Login Audit Trails
threats.description: If login attempts are not logged, users (or attackers) could deny malicious activity.
threats.mitigation:
Implement logging for authentication attempts (success & failure).

Store logs securely with integrity protection.

Regularly review logs for anomalies.

threats.title: Scraping
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #11:
Collecting accessible data and/or processed output from the application
threats.mitigation: Detect fake or compromised accounts, ensure information is accessible only with authentication and authorisation

threats.title: Skewing
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #16:
Automated repeated clicking or requesting or submitting content, affecting application based metrics such as counts, and measures of frequency and/or rate
threats.mitigation: Defences include control of interaction frequency or proper enforcement of a single unique action

threats.title: Spamming
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #17:
Storing malicious such as malware, Iframe distribution, photographs & videos, advertisements, referrer spam and tracking/surveillance code
threats.mitigation: Defences include detecting embedded malicious code, controling interaction frequency and enforcement of a single unique action

threats.title: Expedition
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #6:
Using speed to violate explicit or implicit assumptions about the applications normal use to achieve unfair individual gain
threats.mitigation: Defences include providing enforcement of behavioral workflow and anti-automation

threats.title: Expedition
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #6:
Using speed to violate explicit or implicit assumptions about the applications normal use to achieve unfair individual gain
threats.mitigation: Defences include providing enforcement of behavioral workflow and anti-automation

threats.title: Vulnerability scanning
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #14:
Systematic enumeration and examination in order to find weaknesses and points where a security vulnerability might exist
threats.mitigation: Defence includes providing anti-automation

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #15:
Usage may resemble legitimate application usage but leads to exhaustion of resources
threats.mitigation: Mitigation or prevention such as providing backoff, resource management and avoiding forced deadlock

threats.title: Expedition
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #6:
Using speed to violate explicit or implicit assumptions about the applications normal use to achieve unfair individual gain
threats.mitigation: Defences include providing enforcement of behavioral workflow and anti-automation

threats.title: Vulnerability scanning
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #14:
Systematic enumeration and examination in order to find weaknesses and points where a security vulnerability might exist
threats.mitigation: Defence includes providing anti-automation

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #15:
Usage may resemble legitimate application usage but leads to exhaustion of resources
threats.mitigation: Mitigation or prevention such as providing backoff, resource management and avoiding forced deadlock

threats.title: User Identity Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker may attempt to impersonate a legitimate user by stealing or forging credentials.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strong password policies.

Use MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication).

Lock accounts after multiple failed login attempts.

Implement secure session management.

threats.title: Credential Tampering in Transit
threats.description: Credentials (username, password) could be intercepted and modified if transmitted in plain text.
threats.mitigation:
Use HTTPS/TLS with strong ciphers.

Apply HSTS (HTTP Strict Transport Security).

Use signed session tokens.

threats.title: Lack of Login Audit Trails
threats.description: If login attempts are not logged, users (or attackers) could deny malicious activity.
threats.mitigation:
Implement logging for authentication attempts (success & failure).

Store logs securely with integrity protection.

Regularly review logs for anomalies.

threats.title: Leakage of Sensitive Login Data
threats.description: The system could expose sensitive information (e.g., error messages revealing valid usernames or DB structure).
threats.mitigation:
Use generic login error messages (Invalid credentials).

Do not expose stack traces to users.

Encrypt stored passwords with strong hashing (e.g., bcrypt, Argon2).

threats.title: Login Brute Force or DoS Attack
threats.description: Attackers may flood the login endpoint with requests, causing system unavailability.
threats.mitigation:
Rate-limit login attempts.

Implement CAPTCHA for repeated failed logins.

Monitor and block suspicious IPs.

threats.title: Privilege Escalation via Weak Access Controls
threats.description: A normal user could exploit flaws in session handling or authorization to gain admin access.
threats.mitigation:
Implement role-based access control (RBAC).

Validate user authorization on every request.

Regularly test for privilege escalation vulnerabilities.

threats.title: Internal Services Boundary
threats.description: One service impersonates another
threats.mitigation: mTLS between services.

threats.title: Internal Services B
threats.description: Modified API requests internally
threats.mitigation: Input validation, schema validation.

threats.title: Internal Services Boundary C
threats.description: Services not logging requests
threats.mitigation: Centralized structured logging.

threats.title: Internal Services Boundary D
threats.description: Massive fake orders
threats.mitigation: Rate limit.

threats.title: Internal Services Boundary E
threats.description: Bypass payment flow
threats.mitigation: Enforce state of machine validation.

threats.title: Message Queue
threats.description: Poison messages injected
threats.mitigation: Signed/encrypted massages.

threats.title: Message Queue B
threats.description: Queue flooding
threats.mitigation: Quotas, Monitoring.

threats.title: Message Queue C
threats.description: No trace of consumed events
threats.mitigation: Enable event logging.
